María is a member of the Rosas Rojas ["Red Roses"] communal bank. She lives in the community of La Estancia, in the canton of Paute. This canton has a temperate climate which is well-suited for growing a great variety of fruits and flowers. Its inhabitants work in commerce, animal raising and agriculture. 

María is 47 years old and a single mother, with 4 children aged 27, 20, 16 and 9. Her oldest child, a daughter, is married and independent; her second child, a son, works and helps her economically; her third child, a daughter, is in secondary school; and her youngest, a son, attends a primary school in the canton. Thanks to her sacrifices, she has been able to build a house of her own. 
 
María works in agriculture. She grows vegetables, which she sells in her community. She also raises livestock, guinea pigs and chickens, which she likewise sells in her community. 

She is currently in her third loan cycle with her communal bank, and she will invest this loan in buying chickens, guinea pigs, livestock and animal feed. 

Her goal is to have more animals to raise.

loans.use: to buy chickens, guinea pigs, livestock and animal feed.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 72 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed and has 4 children. 

Yolanda has a shop where she sells snacks, breads & biscuits. She has had this business for 36 years. She requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Yolanda has been a member of HSPFI since 2006. In the future, Yolanda hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Sinout

texts.en:
Sinout is a vegetable seller and raises chickens to sell. Her husband plants mushroom to sell and also raises chickens with his wife. Their income is $15 per day. They have three children, and all of them are studying. 

Every month, Sinout has to spend $75 on food, $15 on electricity, $80 on school fees, $60 on transportation, and $70 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $800 to buy vegetables and meat to sell to the villagers. In the future, she wants to extend her business raising chickens so that she can have enough money to repair her house and make it better.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and meat to sell.

loans.name: Benkadi Minanan  1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENKADI MINANAN 1 sont des femmes mariées  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont en moyenne 7 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames à Kafla, l’un des villages de la commune rurale de Banco, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont essentiellement le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce premier prêt, NOUMOUDJO, la première assise à droite, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour  et de sarclage pour entretenir environs 0,5 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues sur place au marché du village, au niveau du marché de Banco et de N’Golobougou (le principal marché hebdomadaire de la contrée), après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Les femmes du groupe BENKADI MINANAN 1 comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 75.000F CFA environs à la fin de la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of group Benkadi Minanan 1 are married women who are on average 40 years old with seven children. They live in polygamous families in Kafla, one of the villages of the rural township of Banco in Dioila prefecture, Koulikoro region (Mali's second administrative region).
They are collaborating with micro-finance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their activities at the beginning of the rainy season. They mainly cultivate rice and groundnuts. They are on their first collaboration with the organization.
With this first loan, Noumoudjo – the first woman sitting from the right – plans on buying agricultural intrants and small equipment as well as pay for plowing and weeding expenses to maintain about 1.5 acre of rice and groundnuts.
After the harvest, productions are sold locally at the village market as well as in markets in Banco and N’Golobougou, the main weekly market in the area, to a clientele composed of men and women. The women from group Benkadi Minanan 1 are counting on making an average profit of about 75,000 FCFA at the end of the cycle.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide and small equipment.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en: Ronald, 48, is married but separated with 4 children. He lives in Poblacion, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte where he has had an internet business for 10 years. Each month, he earns approximately PHP10000. He has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to purchase computer parts for his business. Ronald became a member of PMPC this year, 2011. In the future, Ronald hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase computer parts for his internet business

loans.name: Ilham

texts.en:
Ilham lives with his wife and son. He manages a trading business. Ilham sells vegetables and fruits in one of the local marketplaces in his hometown of Agsu. 

Ilham's business emerged thanks to his brother's help. He wants to buy his own store in order to make a good profit and improve his living conditions. For this purpose, he has requested a loan of 1000 Azerbaijan new manat (AZN) from AqroInvest and Kiva. Ilham hopes that with the increase in income, he will be able to expand his business.

loans.use: to enlarge his business.

loans.name: Presella

texts.en:
This is Presella, 37, resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Israel, a checker in the port, and is also a mother. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Presella operates an LPG business. She buys Liquefied Petroleum Gas tanks from wholesalers and sells them per tank with a little profit. LPG tanks can range from small to regular size. Aside from this, Presella also retails electronic cell phone loads. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more LPG tanks to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Presella hopes her business will grow more this coming year and dreams of being able to give her children a good, high-quality education through all her hard work at her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God they study.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of Liquefied Petroleum Gas tanks for her business.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 21 years old and a married woman with one child who is not yet in school. She has a business of selling breads in Buluk in South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.

Agnes requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the profits for building a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more breads for resale.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus is 64 years old and lives in Dulapo, Oroquieta City. She is widowed with three children. 

Venus has a general store and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase stock for her general store. 

Venus has been a member of PMPC for five years.

loans.use: to purchase stocks for her general store

loans.name: Luisa Patricia

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Aníbal San Andrés se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi (Portoviejo). Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Luisa tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y de  esta relación tiene tres hijos de 16, 12, y 10 años, los dos  mayores están en colegio y el menor en escuela. Su esposo es obrero.
 
Ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa en la cual vende de todo un poco, allí sus clientes pueden encontrar todo lo necesario, lleva 11 años con su negocio y trabaja todos los días ya que si no se trabaja no hay ganancias y se pierden los clientes, ella desde las  6h00 empieza a atender a sus clientes y cierra a las 20h00.

Este crédito lo quiere invertir en comprar más productos para aumentar su tienda va a comprar arroz, azúcar, carne, pescado y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta por la facilidad para conseguir los créditos.
 
Su sueño es tener una tienda mucho más grande.
texts.en:
The Aníbal San Andrés communal bank meets every two weeks in the Montecristi Cantón (Portoviejo).  This place is famous for its straw hats.

This is where we meet Luisa, age 33.  She is married and has three children; ages 16, 12, and 10.  The two oldest are in high school, and the youngest goes to elementary school.  Her husband is a workman.

She has a grocery store in her house where she sells a little of everything.  Her customers can find everything they need there.  She has had her business for 11 years, and she works every day.  If she does not work there is no income, and she loses customers.  She starts tending to her customers at 6:00 a.m. and she closes at 8:00 p.m.

She wants this loan to buy more products in order to expand her store.  She will buy rice, sugar, meat, fish, and other basic needs products.  She has been in her communal bank since it started.  She likes the ease of getting the loans.

Her dream is to have a much bigger store.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, meat, fish, and other basic needs products.

loans.name: Anointed Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Harare. This is Cuthbert, aged 41. He is married and has three children, all of whom are attending school. He also cares for one dependent.

Cuthbert runs a retail business selling grocieries. The business has been in operation for 3 years. He says the main challenges he faces include competition in terms of pricing and duty charges on basic commodities. Cuthbert has requested a loan of $400.00 to buy groceries. He says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will enhance his life in terms of providing basic needs. In the future, Cuthbert plans to open a wholesale shop or a supermarket.

loans.use: to buy groceries for sale in his shop

loans.name: Raila

texts.en: Raila is a 51-year-old woman, who has been engaged in milk sales for the last four years.  Rakhila is married and has five children.  She has two milking cows and sells milk and homemade yoghurt to the local people.  Raila's profit in this business is 150 AZN per month.  This is the only financial income in her family and Raila is aiming to expand it.  To do that she has applied for a 1000 AZN loan to purchase one milking cow and fodder.

loans.use: to purchase one milking cow and fodder.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: Oscar, de 37 años es un hombre hábil. Vive en compañía de Rosalina, su esposa desde hace 7 años. Ambos tienen 3 hijos: Tania, Cintia y Nicol, a los que cuida en su casa propia, ubicada en la localidad de Conopa. El trabajo al que se dedica es la agricultura, sus principales sembríos son de Habas, trigo y cebada; los que cuida por ocasiones, pues alquila un cuarto en la ciudad, donde sus hijos viven; pues ellos estudian ahí. Pero como él tiene terrenos propios en su pueblo y ya es conocido, pasa la mayor parte de su tiempo ahí. Además cuida de sus animales como vacas, cerdos y burros que vende cuando ya están maduros. Hace poco incursionó en la venta de agregados como arena fina, gruesa, piedra y demás. Cuenta que ahí le va muy bien, tanto así que piensa invertir más para aprovechar el buen negocio que tiene. Él pertenece al grupo solidario “el vencedor” y este es el primer crédito con MFP, donde agradece el apoyo que recibe; pues le permite progresar en su negocio. Además promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas, pues su asociación lo conforman personas responsables y solidarias. Oscar de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de herramientas para preparar el terreno a la espera de sus sembríos de habas y cebada.
texts.en:
Oscar, age 37, is a skilled man. He lives with Rosalina, his wife of seven years. They have three children: Tania, Cintia and Nicol. They live in their own home in Conopa. Oscar works in agriculture. His main crops are beans, wheat and barley. He also rents a room in the city, where his children live; they study there. But since he has his own lands in his village and is already known as a farmer, he spends most of his time there. He also cares for animals such as cows, hogs, and donkeys, which he sells once they are grown. He also recently started selling items such as fine sand, coarse sand, stones, and other such items.
He tells us that it has been going very well for him, so he plans to invest more in order to get the most out of his business. He belongs to the "El Vencedor" ["The Victor"] communal bank, and this is his first loan with MFP. He is grateful for the support that he is receiving; it will allow him to progress with his business. He also promises to be punctual with the payment of his quotas. His bank is made up of responsible and united people. Upon receiving your support, Oscar will invest the requested money in the purchase of tools for preparing his land in preparation for sowing beans and barley.

loans.use: to buy agricultural tools.

loans.name: Shalom 5 & 6 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of the “Shalom 5 & 6” group, located in the town of Hato Mayor, which is one of the most rural towns in the Dominican Republic, surrounded by mountains and lush vegetation.

Maria is running a business selling clothing. She is the mother of three children, but only one lives with her and her long term partner. She tells us that her most difficult challenge is to have her own house, built in a concrete block structure. Her most favorite activity is working and doing business. This is her 9th loan, after having repaid her previous loans satisfactorily. She has had her business for around six years, starting with the first loan she received from us. 

Maria will use this loan to purchase jeans, shirts, underwear and women's clothes such as blouses, skirts, underwear and other items. She is planning to use her business profits to save because she wants to start building her house. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: to buy clothing for her business (pants, shirts, underwear, and blouses).

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Tuya is 51 years old and lives with her husband in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar City, Mongolia. Her kids are all independent and employed. 

Tuya operates a bakery business. She started her bakery business in 2007. Even though her bakery is small, it is well known around the neighborhood for excellent taste. She bakes two kinds of breads. Her product demand is increasing; however, she couldn't keep up with it due to the shortage of raw materials. She is requesting 700,000 Mongolian tughriks (MNT) to buy one ton of flour and one ton of coal.

loans.use: To buy one ton of flour and one ton of coal.

loans.name: Marisol Rosario

texts.es:
Marisol es una joven emprendedora de 21 años, natural de San Vicente de Cañete, conocido popularmente como Cañete, Perú. Ubicado alrededor de una hora y media al sur de Lima, Cañete, con sus playas de arena, ruinas pre-incas, y la producción del adorado nacional licor de Perú, el Pisco (una especie de aguardiente de uva), ha sido durante mucho tiempo un destino turístico para los peruanos adinerados. Pero la verdadera Cañete es una ciudad cálida y tranquila con una gran población afro-peruana, los restos de un camino indígena, y las influencias del imperio español. La ciudad, junto con otros cerca de la costa del Pacífico, fue dañado durante el 2001 y 2007 terremotos Perú, pero ha soportado como lo ha hecho durante gran parte de su historia, nuestra cliente vive en esta ciudad, en casa de sus tíos, a los cuales apoya con los frutos de su trabajo.

Marisol es una mujer muy empeñosa y responsable, ella tiene una amplia experiencia en el negocio de venta y reparaciones de equipos celulares desde hace 4 años, tuvo la iniciativa de incursionar en este negocio ya que veía en ella esta habilidad, y también se encontró influenciada por la gran acogida que tienen estos productos en los pobladores de su comunidad. Marisoltiene una gran cantidad de clientes gracias a la amabilidad que brinda en la atención a sus clientes y también por la calidad de los productos que ofrece. Actualmente desea que los prestatarios Kiva puedan ayudarla y así compré más celulares modernos y pueda ofrecer una mayor variedad de los mismos, esta iniciativa le permitirá incrementar aún más la venta de sus productos. Esta nueva idea de negocio le permitirá seguir confiando en cumplir su sueño de "Tener más locales donde vender celulares"
texts.en:
Marisol, 21, is a young entrepreneur from San Vicente de Cañete, known as Cañete, Perú. Cañete is located 1.5 hours away from Lima and due to its sandy beaches, pre-Incan ruins and production of Peru’s favorite spirit, Pisco (a sort of grape distilled drink), has for a long time been a tourist destination for wealthy Peruvians. The real Cañete, though, is a warm and calm city with a large Afro-Peruvian population, the remains of an indigenous path and the influence of the Spanish Empire. Along with many others in Perú, this city was damaged during the 2001 and 2007 earthquakes but it has survived as always. Our client lives in this city with her aunt and uncle, who are supported by her work. 

Marisol is an entrepreneurial and responsible woman with a broad experience in selling and repairing cell phones. She had the idea to start this business 4 years ago because she felt she had the skills for it and saw the demand potential in her community. She has a large number of customers because of her kindness when dealing with them and the quality of her products. Currently she’d like Kiva loaners to help her so she can purchase more modern phones, thus offering a wider variety to her clients. This initiative will allow her to further increase her sales and will also allow her to remain confident in her dream of “having more stores for selling cell phones.”

loans.use: to purchase cell phones for selling them

loans.name: Annastacia

texts.en: Annastacia is 50 years old and married with two children who are one and five years old. She sells tomatoes, potatoes and cereals to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years. Her other source of income is from farming. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to expand her business. She hopes to see her business grow to a wholesale one in the future. She has applied for 20,000 Kenya Shillings to buy tomatoes, potatoes and cereals.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, potatoes and cereals

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace lives in yambio. She sells food stall, and has been in business for five years. She is 30 year old, married, and has four children; three of them are still in school. 

Grace heard about BRAC South Sudan from a credit officer. This is her first loan from BRAC. She has requested a loan of 500 Sudanese pounds in order to purchase beans, rice. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the children’s school fee.

loans.use: to purchase beans, rice for sale.

loans.name: Gloria Estela

texts.en:
My name is Gloria Estela and I have been working with the detailing and selling of bed clothing for five years. I have many clients who have their own stores who ask me for bedsheets, pillowcases, and cushions for their clients. Thanks to my good work and my prices I have been able to continue to sell and support my children with their studies. Now, I need materials to embrioder a large order that I have been commissioned.

Loan Use: Purchase of fabric, thread, laces, decorative ribbon and other items.

Me llamo Gloria Estela y me dedico a la elaboracion y venta de ropa de cama desde hace 5 años. Tengo muchos clientes de tiendas que me hacen pedidos de cameras, sobrefundas, cojines para sus clientes, gracias al buen trabajo y precios que tengo he podido vender y apoyar a mis hijos en sus estudios. En este momento necesito materiales para poder elaborar un pedido grande que tengo por encargo.

loans.use: Compra de tela, hilos, encajes, cinta decorativa y otros.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sirote would like to buy more steers

loans.name: Karoline

texts.en:
Karoline has just joined the SPBD program.  She joined in order to invest in her small plot of land and develop it into a taro plantation.  She was born and raised in the small Samoan village in which she still lives in with her husband.  Neither she nor her husband are employed so this venture in cultivating taro is their only source of income.  

Unfortunately, Karoline’s husband has some significant health problems. This means that it falls on her to start up this plantation.  They hope that after the initial harvests, they can hire some local boys to do much of the work under the supervision of Karoline’s husband.  Historically, they have had to rely on the generosity of their relatives to survive.  Although Karoline gave birth to three children, these children are living with relatives because Karoline and her husband cannot afford to raise them.  Karoline’s dream is financial independence and the ability to provide for her husband and children.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Aflatun

texts.en: Aflatun R. is 42 years old, is married, and has 3 children. He works as a teacher in a local school. At the same time he is keeping a calf for meat purposes. He is a successful businessman and is not going to stop. He developed his business and borrowed a 1200 USD loan from Aqroinvest CU to purchase one cow and one calf.

loans.use: Going to purchase one cow and one calf

loans.name: Floric

texts.en: Floric (in a white coat) is a 45 year old trained nurse. She is a single mother of two daughters. Floric became a registered nurse in 1984. She worked with the government hospital for three years before starting her own clinic in 1989 .  Her clinic is situated in the Runyenjes Embu District. She offers a variety of services including general services, family planning, child welfare and operates a laboratory. The community appreciates the quality services that her facility provides. She requires US $1200 to further expand her clinic.

loans.use: Clinic expansion

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is an artisan who makes “morraletes”, colored plastic bags that are used locally to tote purchases from the market. She is 22 years old and has two children. She belongs to a group called Brocal 5 along with Manuela Diaz Ruiz and Micaela Ruiz L., also artisans. Juana would like use her loan to expand her business by purchasing different colored plastics and wood molds.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

JUANA es artesana, teje morraletas hechos de plástico que utiliza la gente de su localidad para cargar las cosas que se compran en el mercado. Ella tiene 22 años, dos hijos. Pertenece al grupo llamado Brocal 5 junto con doña Manuela Díaz Ruiz (artesana) y doña Micaela Ruiz López (artesana). Con sus prestamos compraran plástico al por mayor en su variedad de colores y moldes de madera.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her business.

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr:
Mrs. Abla A. was born May 31, 1977 in Lomé. She lives in the Djidjolé district of Lomé, where she has a bar/restaurant and specializes in serving “foufou” (mashed yams). She is a married mother who is alone responsible for taking care of her two (02) children. She is requesting a loan of $200 for the wholesale purchase of cassava, yams and corn from local farmers. This will allow her to expand her business and to develop a loyal customer base.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Abla A. est née le 31 Mai 1977 à Lomé. Demeurant dans le quartier de Djidjolé à Lomé, elle est gérante d’un restaurant-bar de foufou (igname pilée). Elle est mariée et mère de deux (02) enfants qui sont à sa charge. Elle sollicite une somme de $200 pour acheter chez les paysans les maniocs, les ignames, le maïs en gros. Ceci lui permettra d’agrandir son commerce et de fidéliser sa clientèle.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of yams, cassava and corn

loans.name: Menelio

texts.es:
Don Menelio is 24 years old, married to doña Nelly Fleitas who is also a merchant, and they have a two-year old son.

Mr. Menelio is a vendor, he owns a motorcycle for distribution and debt collection of the merchandise he sells. Previously he worked as an employee with a private enterprise. His father, who is also a vendor, supported him to become independent and presently don Menelio has more than three-hundred clients in several parts of the country.

The requested loan will be invested in buying jeans, t-shirts, sports footwear, slippers, sheets, bedspreads, tablecloths, stockings, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Menelio tiene 24 años esta casado con la Sra. Nelly Fleitas que también es comerciante, tienen un hijo pequeño de dos años de edad.

El señor es vendedor ambulante, posee una moto con la que realiza los repartos y cobranzas de las mercaderías que vende. Anteriormente trabajaba como empleado en una empresa privada, su padre que dedica a lo mismo, lo apoyó para que se independizara y actualmente posee más de trescientos clientes en varios puntos del país.

El préstamo que solicita desea invertirlo en la compra de jeans, remeras, calzados deportivos, zapatillas, sábanas, colchas, manteles, medias, etc.

loans.use: Purchase jeans, t-shirts, sports footwear, slippers, sheets, bedspreads, tablecloths, stockings, etc. to to meet customers' demands.

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
I am Nusrat A. and I live in the small city Borofewala, Pakistan. I am applying for my second loan. Last year, my husband and I took out a loan to invest in the snack stand he operates in a nearby market. This year, we are applying for a loan to buy a rickshaw, which he would like to rent out to various drivers. We hope that with this venture, our income will double. I am a mother of four children, two girls and two boys, all of whom are in school.

I lead a group which includes the following women: Fareeda B., who needs a loan to help her brother supply eggs to different shops in our city. Zahida P. needs the loan for her bicycle repair shop. Manzooran B. will use the loan to improve her crockery store. Khursheed B. wants to buy oranges to sell from her cart. Please help all of us.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw and other items for various small businesses

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes M. has 3 children and is married to a taxi driver.  To help support her family she makes and sells “kenkey”.  Kenkey is a very popular Ghanaian dish and is served with stew.  She is requesting $225 to buy corn so she can produce kenkey in larger quantities.  Agnes is also a member of a lending group called “Anointing Group”, which consists of 10 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To buy corn to produce kenkey.

loans.name: Karla Anabel

texts.es:
Mrs. Karla R. is 37 years old. She lives in the Barrio Hialeah area of the city, along with her husband and her 5 year old son. Her business involves the selling of Natural products/medicine. She is a young and enterprising and has worked at this business for 3 years in order to help her husband. The name of the powder that she makes is called Neutrodor, and is made for the feet. She mixes the powder and ingredients together and sells it at markets, general stores and other businesses. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more ingredients so that she can make more product to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Karla R. de 37 años de edad, vive en el Barrio Hialeah, es casada y su esposo se dedica a la venta de medicina Natural, tienen una niña de 5 años de edad. Karla es una mujer joven y emprendedora que para ayudar a su esposo tiene 3 años de Elaborar un talco especialmente para los pies llamado Neutrodor, el cual ella misma empaca y los vende al por mayor en pulperías, ventas, y otros negocios. Ella consiguió los ingredientes y aprendió la elaboración y ese es su negocio, Este negocio le ha permitido apoyar en forma significativa a su casa y darle a su hija las necesidades necesarias por su edad. Solicita un crédito para comprar materia prima y elaborar mayor cantidad de producto.

loans.use: To purchase more high quality ingredients so that she can make more of the talc product to sell.  (Comprar materia prima para elaboración de talco)

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es:
Santiago is a single man but he has three children. Eleven years ago he began selling fruit and vegetables from a tricycle. When he found himself unemployed, he learned this occupation from a brother-in-law who taught him and little by little, he began generating income. He wishes now to sell hot dogs, also.

Santiago is requesting a loan of US $350 which he will repay in 6 months to purchase a hot dog cart. With your help, Santiago will be able to move forward.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva volunteer.

Santiago es soltero pero tiene 3 hijos, hace 11 años el empezó vendiendo frutas y verduras en un triciclo al quedarse desempleado este oficio lo aprendió de un cuñado que le enseño, y poco a poco fue generando ingresos. Ahora desea vender también hot dogs.

Ahora solicita un crédito por US $350 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar un carrito para vender hot dogs. Con tu ayuda Santiago saldrá adelante.

loans.use: Purchase a hot dog cart.

loans.name: Rose Nalwadda's Group

texts.en:
Rose is leader of a group of four members. She is 40 years old and married with four children aged between 22 and 12 years. All of them are in school. The community she resides and works in is an urban slum in a low-lying area that is vulnerable to floods.

She has been selling bananas (matooke) for 10 years. Presently, she works from under a tree after buying the produce from vendors who distribute it from trucks. She faces challenges of unstable prices, stiff competition, and the hazards of the weather.

She has been able to contribute to the running of her home and she would like to buy a plot of land and construct a house.

Rose has successfully paid back four loans.

loans.use: To be able to stock more food at a time.

loans.name: Hiy Kaing Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hiy K. is the group leader of Hiy K. Group in Kol Kup Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a housewife and the mother of two children, one of whom is a palm juice collector, while the other is attending school. Her husband, Mr. Hoeurn Sam, is a subsistence farmer.

Nowadays, Mr. Hoeurn Sam's plantation faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to purchase more fertilizer to support his field. Therefore, Mrs. Hiy K. has applied for a loan to buy fertilizer for her husband's business. Previously, she obtained another loan to buy fertilizer for her husband’s field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her husband's  business

loans.name: Teresa Jesús

texts.es:
Teresa Jesús P. D. C. is divorced, 53 years of age, she studied nutrition and works in Salaverry as head of social programmes. She has 4 children, two who work and 2 who are still studying. She lives in Salaverry, in Trujillo, La Libertad. Apart from working in the area, she also sells cosmetic products. It was her niece who encouraged her with the business, which is going well. She sells products to work colleagues and also relatives. Teresa is a dynamic lady, and despite her busy life, she is involved in the Mothers Club “SANTA ROSA D. LIMA”. Her friend encouraged her to join the Banco Comunal “LAS EMPRENDEDORAS”, and she has been working with Manuela Ramos for three years. With her first loan of S/. 300.00, she bought catalogue offers in order to offer her customers greater variety and make the most of the rewards. With this loan of S/. 800.00, which she will pay back in 6 months, she intends to open a new business selling threads, buttons, fasteners, and silk lace as there is a need for this sort of business in her area. Her aim is to become a great business woman, and her wish is to have a car of her own to get about.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

La señora Teresa Jesús P. D. C., es divorciada, tiene 53 años, estudió nutrición, trabaja en la Municipalidad D. Salaverry tiene el cargo D. jefa D. programas sociales, tiene 04 hijos, 02 trabajan y 02 son estudiantes, vive en el distrito D. Salaverry en la Provincia D. Trujillo en el Departamento D. La Libertad. Aparte D. trabajar en el municipio se dedica también a la venta D. productos cosméticos, fue una sobrina quien la animó a incursionar en este negocio y le va bien, venD. sus productos a compañeras y compañeros D. trabajo y también a sus familiares. La señora Teresa es muy dinámica pese a sus múltiples actividades integra el Club D. Madres “SANTA ROSA D. LIMA” su compañera la animó a participar en el Banco Comunal “LAS EMPRENDEDORAS”, tiene tres años trabajando con Manuela Ramos y con el primer préstamo D. S/. 300.00, compró las ofertas del catálogo para tener variedad D. productos y aprovechar los premios. Con el préstamo D. S/. 800.00 que cancelará en un plazo D. 06 meses, tiene pensado abrir un nuevo negocio D. venta D. hilos, botones, cierres, blondas ya que un negocio así hace falta en su localidad. Tiene como meta ser una gran empresaria, su anhelo es tener un carro para movilizarse.

loans.use: To purchase threads, buttons, fasteners etc

loans.name: Yohana De La Concepc

texts.es:
Mrs. A. R. is 33 years old, she is married and hast two young children who are in third and fifth grades respectively in school, and her husband works selling chickens with her, which is their only source of income; she has the goal to develop her business with the loan to increase her inventory of chickens. She later on sells them to near by grocery stores; her biggest dream is to see her children as professionals one day. The loan will be used as working capital to buy vitamins, food and vaccines for the chickens; her wish it to install a farm with good infrastructure and create employment. This activity started by her own initiative due the unemployment and way to improve her live.
 Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La señora A. R., tiene 33 años de edad, es casada tiene 2 hijos menoes de edad, ambos cursan el tercer grado y quinto grado respectivamente de primaria, su compañero de vida se dedica al comercio de venta de pollo en pieza en conjunto con su esposa lo que constituye su unica fuente de ingresos; la señora tiene el proposito de desarrollar su negocio con el apoyo de los creditos ya que ello le ha ayudado a tener un mayor inventario de aves de corral que posteriormente en conjutno con su esposo destaza y entrega pulperias cercanas, su mayor sueño es poder ver coronada una carrera profesinal para sus hijos con el esfurzo y sacrificio de su trabajo, El financiamiento actual sera utilizado para capital de trabajo como es la compra de vitaminas, concentrado, vacunas para los pollos;  su deseo es poder instalar una granja con condiciones de infraestructura y poder genar empleos que en la actualidad no posee, ella tiene cuatro años de dedicarse a esta actividad la cual surge como una iniciativa propia ante el desempleo y una manera de querer superase en la vida

loans.use: Working Capital / Capital de trabajo

loans.name: Qatiba

texts.en: Qatiba J., 47, is married and has two daughters. Her main activity is to sell dairy products as milk and yoghurt. She started her business in 2002, because the income that her husband was earning was not enough to cover their basic family needs. She married when she had just finished high school, and until 2002 Qatiba was a full-time housewife, but in 2002 financial difficulties pushed her to start her own business. Her daughters help her a lot in looking after the cows, but as prices in the country increase, there are no additional financial resources for her family. So Qatiba decided to expand her business and applied for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase two more cows. One of her daughters decided to get university degree and now Qatiba’s wants to help her child achieve what she could not get in her own youth.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Govhar

texts.ru: Джамолова Говхар жительница района Абдурахмони Джоми. Возраст 40 лет. Замужем и имеет пятерых детей. Домохозяйка , но занимается  растениеводством. Имеет участок земли , который засеивает пшеницей. Так и планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы закупить семена и удобрения. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 10 месяцев.
texts.en:
Govhar J. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. She is 40 years old, married and has five wonderful children. Govhar mainly works as a housewife but also grows wheat on a small plot of land on the side. To finance her purchase of seeds and fertilizer she wants to take out this loan which she plans to pay back in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es: Alicia tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos Cristian y Juan Carlos. Se de dedica a la elaboración y venta de artesanía, como balsitas hechas a totora, joyeros, collares, móviles, etc, ella vende estos artículos a los turistas que visitan su Isla. La alegre Alicia recibe hospitalariamente a los turistas mostrándole su isla, vistiéndolos con los trajes típicos de la zona y compartiendo toda su cultura. Le gusta mucho compartir e interactuar con los turistas, a quienes ven como amigos que llegan de visita. Este es su primer préstamo en Microfinanzas Prisma. Con el dinero comprará más materiales para elaborar sus artesanías y darles un mejor acabado, y hacerlas más atractivas a los turistas.
texts.en:
Alicia is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children, Christian an dJuan Carlos. She makes and sells artisan pieces such as small reed rafts, jewelry, necklaces, mobiles, etc. She sells these items to the tourists that visit her island. Alicia happily receives her tourists with great hospitality and shows them her island, dressing them with the typical clothing of the area and sharing her culture with them. She likes to share and interact with the tourists, whom she sees as friends coming for a visit. This is her first loan with Microfinancas Prisma. With the money she will buy more materials to make her artisan pieces and give them a better finish and detail, making them more attractive to the tourists.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to make artisan pieces

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara R. sells clothing and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Sara is 27 years old, married, and has one child. Her husband is a policeman. Her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to keep sending her child to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. These programs and services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Pay school fees for her child

loans.name: Claude

texts.en:
Claude is a 54-year-old woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Claude has been a seamstress for 18 years. She sews clothes for woman and children. Claude requested a loan of $1000 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase fabrics and thread; she also wants to do some maintenance work on her sewing machine. This is the first time that Claude has requested a loan.
Claude hopes that the loan will help improve her condition. Her clients are her friends, family members, and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had difficulty buying merchandise. She decided on doing this business because of her creativity and her perfectionism in her work.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and thread

loans.name: Kosar M. Manzoor Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is a 39-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 20 years. She completed her education up to 5th standard and couldn’t study further due to the meager income of her father. She is married to a man whose name is M. M. and he is a mason by profession. She is the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. Her elder son is employed in a motor workshop. The others have no jobs. Her husband only gets income when he gets a contract to construct a building. Now he is planning to start a shuttering business to earn good income. Kosar baji helps him by doing embroidery on dresses. She collects orders from her neighbors and charges them $3 per dress. She is applying for a loan to buy beams and rope to start a shuttering business.

She is the group leader for some more women from her locality. Taj baji wants a loan to buy tires for her tractor. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shama baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for shuttering business

loans.name: Noah

texts.en:
Noah O. is fifty-one years old, married and has five children, two of whom are boys and three girls. He says currently, one of them is in the senior high school, another in the junior high school, while the rest are in the primary school. His wife is a trader as well as a farmer. He lives with his family in a rented house at Simpa. Simpa is a small farming community which is a few kilometers from Tarkwa in the Western Region of Ghana. Most of the inhabitants combine farming with other economic activities.

Noah is a fitting mechanic by profession. He repairs damaged vehicles in his community. He owns a workshop in which he works. Noah also sells car spare parts in his shop to customers. He wants a loan to buy more spare parts such as driving mirrors, wind screens, head lights, hoods, etc. According to him, he has trained a number of apprentices who have graduated and are running their own shops. Noah has been in business for over twenty years. Noah desires to help his children climb the academic ladder to higher levels.

loans.use: To buy vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Nisrine

texts.en:
Nisrine is a 29-year-old woman who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon with her husband and their three children. Nisrine has owned a hairdressing salon for seven years. She also has been selling makeup for four years.

Nisrine requested a loan of $500 from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase makeup and accessories for her salon. This is the first time that Nisrine has requested a loan.

Nisrine is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and she is good at her work. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She decided on doing her business because of her experience as well as to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her business and opening a makeup shop.

loans.use: To purchase makeup and accessories for her salon

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
" Ever since I was just a 10-year-old kid, I already knew the proper way to farm rice," says Luzviminda C.. "My parents are farmers, they taught me everything about planting rice, removing weeds and harvesting a lot in our farm," she added. Luzviminda is 44 years old and has 8 children. Some of her children quit school to help them in managing their farm. Her husband, Eduardo C., is not happy about that, that is why they work harder now, to support their children, especially the ones in schools.

Luzviminda is asking for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer, herbicide and pesticide for her farm. The loan will truly help her grow her harvest to support her family better.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines. CEVI helps people, especially the poor, to start and run their own business. CEVI reaches out to more people so that they can have their own livelihood. CEVI provides not only credit but training and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Palema Kalifa

texts.en: Palema Kalifa A., 36, is married with six children. She has many years of experience in the plantation business, and sells to the public five days per week. Palema Kalifa has no previous loans with Kiva partner, SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 WST. SPBD loans are Palema Kalifa’s only access to capital because she has never qualified for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weedkiller, chemicals, knives and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Brak

texts.en: Brak T. is 38 years old and lives with her husband in Battambang Province. Since 2000, she has been making and selling brooms in the local market to earn a living and is able to make $5 per day. Her husband, a construction worker building houses, also earns $5 per day.  Brak is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike and a trailer so that she can transport her brooms to sell at the market and other locales.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and a trailer.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a retired civil servant. He has a pig farm where he rears pigs. Peter is 61 years old and married with 2 children. He hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more pigs to sell. He says thanks.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking oil and soda.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.es:
La señora Elisa pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Azangaro, Provincia de Azangaro, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 28 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, es madre de 02 hijos y tiene estudios de secundaria incompleta (4to grado),  vive en el Barrio Revolución.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 01 año, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, dinero que invirtió en la elaboración de alimentos (desayunos al paso). 

Con este préstamo de S/. 300.00, comprará frutas, quinua, leche, cañihua, etc. 
para la preparación de desayunos al paso, esta actividad la realiza por las mañanas.

A ella le gustaría poner un negocio de compra y venta de ropa.

Manifiesta que le gustan  las charlas y los ahorros que ha podido generar.
texts.en:
Elisa belongs to the Community Bank "Las Poderosas de Santa Rosa", located in the district and province of Azangaro in Puno. She is 28 years old, she is married common-law, and she is mother of 2 children. She did not finish high school (grade 10). She lives in the region of Barrio Revolucion.

She has been with Manuela Ramos (Kiva Field Partner) for 1 year. Her first loan was in the amount of S/.300 neuvos soles, funds that were invested in preparing foods (fast food breakfast).

This loan of S/.300 will be used to purchase fruit, quinoa grains, milk, and canihua grains etc. to prepare breakfast foods, a daily morning routine.

She would like to set up a business buying and seling clothing.

She says that she loves chatting, and the saving she has managed to put away.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruit, quinoa grains, milk, and canihua grains etc.

loans.name: Rahinatu

texts.en: Rahinatu is forty-six years old. She is married and has eight children who are all still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. She is a food vendor. She cooks the food at her residence and sells by the road side in the day time. She buys bags of rice and other ingredients from Kumasi market. Rahinatu has been in business for over thirty years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice in bulk. She aspires to give her children good education.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice in bulk.

loans.name: Carmen Maruja

texts.es:
Carmen vive en la AV/Buenos Aires de la zona Tembladerani en la ciudad de La Paz.
 
La señora vive junto a sus hijos y trabaja como portera dentro del mismo Celegio, en donde  tiene puesto de venta de dulces.

Gracias a los préstamos otorgados anteriormente, cuenta con un pequeño capital de trabajo con el cual tiene  mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Carmen lives on Buenos Aires Avenue in the Tembladerani district of the city of La Paz. She lives with her children and works as a school caretaker. She also sells candy from a stand in the same building where she works.

Thanks to her previous loans, she was able to secure operating capital to help her improve her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Nub

texts.en:
Nub S., age 28, is married and has two young children. She lives with her husband and children in Takeo province. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of weaving at home, earning approximately US $4 per day which is the primary source of income for the family. Her husband works as a teacher of a local public school, and he also sells scarves and car washer made from pieces of fabrics, earning an income of US $3 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income. She is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport his fabrics and scarves to sell. By doing so, she hopes she will be able to generate more income and save more money to raise a good standard of living.

loans.use: motorbike purchase

loans.name: Aparicia

texts.es:
Aparicia es comerciante de abarrotes, papas cebollas y demás, tiene un puesto en la ceja ciudad de el Alto, su esposo trabaja en la policía, es su fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre la manutención de sus tres hijos que dependen de ellos; los menores todavía se encuentran estudiando, la hija mayor ayuda con el armado de su puesto, vive en anticrético en una casa ubicada en la Zona de Villa Tunari de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará para la compra de mercadería (chuño, maiz, etc.) y así poder vender más y mejorar sus ingresos económicos.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por Aparicia.
texts.en:
Aparicia sells groceries, such as potatoes, onions, and more at her stand in La Ceja in the city of El Alto. Her husband works in the police force, which provides a source of income to cover the maintenance of their three children that depend on them. The younger children are currently still studying; her older daughter, who lives in a house located in the zone of Villa Tunari in the city of El Alto, helps her with the grocery stand. The loan will be used for the purchase of merchandise (flour, corn, etc.) in order to be able to sell more and improve her economic income. This is her second credit with Impro, and upon evaluation she qualifies for the requested loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of merchandise, such as flour, corn, potatoes, onions, etc., for sale at her stand located in La Ceja in the city of El Alto.

loans.name: Gerardo Ramón

texts.es:
Gerardo Ramón S. R. es originario de la ciudad de Granada, llamada por los nicaragüenses “La Gran Sultana”, por su volcán, antiguamente conocido como “El Sultán”.

Gerardo posee dos tipos de negocios que le han permitido salir adelante, subsistir y mejorar sus condiciones de vida. El primero es la agricultura, que realiza desde hace más de quince años; Posee 5 manzanas de tierra y siembra Maíz, frijoles y yuca. En este tipo de negocio la ganancia se mira a largo plazo, por lo tanto como el mismo dice “Por la necesidad” tomó la iniciativa de invertir en otro tipo de negocio a menor plazo, éste es la compra de arboles para leña.

Inició con 5 fletes de leña; pero con los créditos que se le han proporcionado y el trabajo que el realiza, actualmente trabaja hasta con 20 fletes de leña. Su meta es llegar a los 130 fletes. 

Leva 25 ciclos de crédito con ADIM, más de 6 años de trabajar con la institución y se siente muy satisfecho, orgulloso de sus logros y cree que va a alcanzar sus metas pronto, puesto que como el mismo dice “Me ha ido bonito”.
texts.en:
Gerardo Ramón S. R. is originally from the city of Grenada, which is called “The Great Sultan” by Nicaraguans because of its ancient volcano known as “the Sultan”.

Gerardo has managed two businesses in order to get ahead, survive, and improve his quality of life. His first business is in agriculture, which he started more than 15 years ago. He owns 5 plots of land for planting corn, beans, and cassava. This is his long-term business that serves as his primary source of income. He took the initiative to start another business out of necessity, buying timber used for firewood. Originally he started with 5 shipments of wood, but loans have helped him acquire up to 20 shipments at a time. His goal is to be able to handle 130 shipments.

Gerardo has already taken out 25 loans from ADIM over a 6 year relationship with the Institution. He is very happy and proud of his accomplishments. He believes he will reach his goals soon because he keeps telling himself, “You can do this.”

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase firewood & supplies for planting corn, beans, and cassava

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: aménagement local

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia is twenty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom go to school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Afia is a trader. She runs a cold store in her community. She procures fresh fish and meat from big cold storage places in nearby towns. Afia supplies to food vendors and retailers in her community. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure cartons of fresh fish and meat in bulk. Afia is hopeful of improving upon her standard of living and wants to give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish & meat in bulk

loans.name: Mirian Geraldina's Group

texts.es:
el grupo solidario denominado las brisas del Henecan esta integrado por tres personas un hombre y dos mujeres, se han asociado con el fin de obtener capital de trabajo.
estas son las actividades que ellos realizan:

las señora Dayani Mercedes C. tiene 22 años de edad, vive en union libre con el señor Elvin Leonel Perez, tiene un hijo pequeño.
su negocio es la compra venta de ropa usada que la vende en su casa, en colonias y barrios de san lorenzo esta solicitando un credito para invertir en ropa para vender en navidad.
 
la señora Mirian Geraldina E. tiene 39 años de edad, es madre soltera tiene dos hijos. vive con sus padres.
Su negocio es la compra venta de ropa nueva y usada, lacteos, chiclera esta solicitando el credito para comprar un fardo de ropa, e invertir en los lacteos.
 
el señor Fredys Omar Funes tiene 25 años de edad, vive en union libre con la señora Grecia Maricela Perez, el se dedica a la compra venta de pescado y tamabien a la venta de ropa esta actividad la
realiza desde hace 03 años. su esposa le ayuda con las ventas. esta solicitando el credito para capital de trabajo quiere invertir para la navidad ya que las ventas son buenas para esa 
epoca.
texts.en:
The Solidarity Group named “Las Brisas del Henecan” (The Breeze of Henecan) consists of three people, one man and two women. They have partnered together in order to obtain working capital. Their business activities are described below:

Sra. Dayani Mercedes C. is 22 years old and in a common law marriage with Sr. Elvin Leonel Perez. They have a young son. Her business involves buying secondhand clothes and selling them either from home or in the neighborhoods of San Lorenzo. She is requesting a loan to invest in more clothing to sell for the Christmas season.

Sra. Mirian Geraldina E. is 39 years old and a single mother of two children. She lives with her parents. Her business involves buying and selling new and used clothing, dairy products, and chewing gum. She is requesting a loan to purchase a bundle of clothing and to invest in more dairy products.

Sr. Fredys Omar Funes is 25 years old and is in a common law marriage with Sra. Grecia Maricela Perez. His business involves buying and selling fish and clothing. He has been engaged in this business activity for 3 years. His wife helps with selling these products. The loan he requested will be used as working capital to invest in more merchandise for the Christmas season, since sales are good during this time of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Esther Wambui

texts.en:
Esther Wambui is an industrious lady aged 40 and a mother of two aged 15 and 13. She is married to Anthony, a businessman aged 46. She has been selling clothes in the heart of Kakamega town for the last five years. She started this business with some funds she had obtained from her husband.

This will be her first loan from KADET. She intends to use the money to increase her stock of clothes to prepare for the holiday season, when demand for clothes is highest. She hopes to make a great profit, since the loan she has accessed from KADET will enable her to stock her business well. She has been supporting some neighbors who are orphans and she projects that since she expects to have increased sales, the aid she offers to these families will also go up.

Esther aspires to expand this business into a wholesale boutique shop. She also has a goal of empowering her children with education in the best way possible. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Danixa

texts.es:
Nuestra socia DANIXA tiene 35 años, es conviviente, es natural de la ciudad del Cusco y pertenece al banco comunal “EMPRENDEDORES DE SAN CRISTOBAL” de la Asociación Arariwa. La socia tiene dos hijos: Álvaro tiene 13 años y Renzo tiene 9 años ambos estudian en el colegio “Salesianos” de la ciudad del Cusco.       
 
La socia es profesional en Obstetricia pero se dedico al negocio de agregados de construcción. Ella y su esposo tienen una empresa procesadora de piedra chancada. Ya son seis años con el trabajo y les ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que ponen en su trabajo. Nuestra socia y su esposo son unos padres, trabajadores y emprendedores que sacan adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para la educación y alimentación de sus hijos. 
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Danixa is 35 years old, in a common law marriage, and a native of Cusco. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Emprendedores de San Cristobal”, which is part of Asociación Arariwa. Danixa has two children, Álvaro (age 13) and Renzo (age 9). Both are students at the Salesianos School in Cusco.

Danixa is an obstetrician by profession, but she also has a business producing construction aggregates. She and her husband manage a company that processes crushed stone. They have been in operation for six years and have done very well as a result of their hard work and effort. Danixa and her husband are diligent, enterprising parents who want to succeed for the sake of their family. She is requesting a loan to educate and feed her children.

Danixa is grateful for this opportunity and promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Educate & feed her children

loans.name: Sapi

texts.en:
Sapi T. is 54 and married with 5 children (ages 15 - 38).  She owns a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam).  Sapi has 3 years of experience in this business.  Sapi needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Sapi joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sapi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Sapi T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen N. is 31 years old and a business man in Kilifi town. He is single and has no children. Stephen has rented a stall where he sells a wide variety of clothes. His business has been there for the last seven years and it has been growing with time.

Stephen has been able to borrow and successfully repay two loans from KADET and is currently borrowing a third loan of 80,000 KES. He plans to purchase more stock of men’s wear and an assortment of Khangas (African printed materials) for the women.

Stephen hopes to expand his business by investing the profit he is making back into his business. He also hopes to open a new stall in the same market in Kilifi.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of men’s wear and an assortment of Khangas for the women.

loans.name: Chepkwony

texts.en:
Chepkwony is a 26-year-old entrepreneur and dairy farmer in the Litein area of the South Rift Valley of Kenya. He's been farming for five years and employs two people. He sells his milk through Kenya Cooperative Creameries and also earns income from a small general store. He previously worked as a motorbike taxi driver. He says that the main challenge to his business is unreliable employees that require close supervision.

He requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 80,000 to purchase a dairy cow, after successfully repaying a previous loan for 45,000. He says he is enjoying good financial services through Juhudi which might not have been available to him otherwise. In the future, he would like to build a modern house, own his own car, and stabilize his family with increased income from farming.

About Juhudi Kilimo

Juhudi Kilimo is an innovative, for-profit social enterprise working with smallholder farmers in Kenya. Juhudi directly finances dairy cows, chickens, agricultural equipment, and other assets that are specifically chosen to create immediate cash flow. Many of the assets are insured to prevent devastating business losses, and targeted technical assistance is provided to farmers, from agricultural training to basic bookkeeping and local market research. For its clients and their families, Juhudi also offers access to medical aid. Through all these services, Juhudi is creating sustainable growth and employment in rural communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Maria Josefa

texts.es: María Josefa L. A., tiene 41 años de edad tiene 4 hijos, ella tiene una tienda (venta de consumo diario) vende: golosinas, dulces, galletas, también vende algo de libreria como; cuadernos, lapices, lapiceros, etc. Tiene el negocio en su casa y solicita este crédito para comprar mas producto para surtir su tienda, también en la misma tienda tiene una tortilleria. Con este negocio ella mantiene a sus hijos, su sueño es tener una tienda mas grande similar a un deposito y también una librería.
texts.en:
María Josefa L. A. is 41 years of age and has 4 children. She has a store (for the sale of convenience items) where she sells: snacks, sweets, and crackers. She also sells office supplies such as notebooks, pencils, mechanical pencils, etc. She runs the business in her house and requests this loan to buy more products to supply her store. In the same store she also sells tortillas. With this business she maintains her children. Her dream is to have a larger store similar to an general store and also a bookstore.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina S., 46, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Julio S., a company employee, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn their living so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her small piggery for several years.

Rosalina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows as added working capital for her business.    

Now with your help, Rosalina would like to apply for a PHP 16,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added working capital to her expanding business by buying feeds for her pigs.

She dreams that her business will grow so that they can have a better life in the future. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying feed for her pigs

loans.name: Jane Fransis

texts.en:
Jane Fransis is a single mother of five children. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a one-room house where she is staying with two people. Jane Fransis takes care of additional family members. There is no electricity or piped water at her home.  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area. She incurs transport costs to and from buying second hand clothes from Owino market. She does her shopping twice a week and buys from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city.  She sells to five customers a day. Jane Fransis sells to all categories of people at retail and works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include rent for her residence plus medication.  Jane Fransis moves door to door while selling her clothes. She has been in this business for five years. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start buying a full bale of used clothes.

Jane Fransis is the one wearing a yellow tunic with her group mates.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothing

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina B. is from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 60 years old. Rosalina is widowed and has three adult children. To make a living, Rosalina owns & operates a business venture preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the ninth loan taken out by Rosalina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 40 years old, married, and has seven children. He lives with his family in Chtoura, in the Bekaa. He has worked as a pick-up driver for the past 14 years. He offers his transportation services in his town and its surroundings; he transports anything he can, depending on his clients’ requests. Ahmad has requested his first loan in order to carry out maintenance work on his pick-up to increase its safety features, as well as save money for his children's school tuition.

loans.use: To carry out maintenance work on his pick-up

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida is a 36-year-old woman from the city of Lahore (famous for its Punjabi foods and historical places). For the past 15 years, she has lived in a 2-room house.

She has completed her education to 10th standard, but could not study further due to the limited financial resources of her family.

She got married at the age of 18. After marriage she started sewing clothes to financially support her husband. He works in Saudi Arabia, so he lives far away from his family. Now she makes embroidered dresses as well, and earns a good income. She utilizes her income for the education of her children and also saves the additional profit.

She works not only to generate income for her family, but also because she loves her work. Her work gives her satisfaction because it enables her to meet the desires of her children and it encourages her husband. 

Sajida is also a very sensible mother. She has four children: one son and three daughters. All of her children are studying because she wants them to have a good future.

She has a brother who lives with her and is involved in making handbags. Sajida wants to help him because he is a very hard worker. She is applying for a loan for the first time from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) to invest in her brother's business so that he may purchase required items for the handbags (leather, cloth, zippers). Helping him increase his income makes Sajida proud.

loans.use: To purchase items to make handbags

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en: Robinah is married with five children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a retail shop in Kawempe selling all types of merchandise like soap, sugar, cooking oil and salt.  She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like one bag of sugar, a carton of salt one jerycan of cooking oil and box soap. She has been in this business for seven years and besides this retail shop she also sells tap (piped) water.  Her major customers are her village mates. She works seven days a week. Robinah‘s business challenges includes seasonality and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo to her shop in Kawempe Nabukalu zone.  She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and own a whole sale shop.  She joined MCDT to acquire more capital as it was giving out timely loans.  Robinah owns and resides in a two roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Monthly expenses includes food medical and school fees

loans.use: To buy suagr, soap, salt and cooking oil

loans.name: Arstaddulam

texts.en:
Artsaddulam C., age 40, lives with her family in a traditional housing tent called a 'ger' in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Their living conditions are good. She started her business career making shoes. Her husband is a driver and has been transporting raw materials from other sub-provinces. 

Artsaddulam is an easy-going, friendly, and precise woman. She says, “We would like to complete our house by this autumn and my dream is to have my own workplace.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase raw materials and complete her house.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and complete her house

loans.name: Franklin Vicente

texts.es:
Frankiln de 50 años, vive en la Perimetral de Guayaquil (perímetro periurbano, que tiene una ecología en disolución). Cuando era joven no tuvo oportunidad de estudiar y tuvo que trabajar en una zapatería, poco a poco aprendió y con sus ahorros decidió independizase y tener su propio negocio. 

Aunque al principio fue muy difícil el continuo con su pequeña zapaterías, arreglando zapatos, cosiéndolos y fabricándolos. Ahora toda su familia le ayuda en al zapatería, trabajan desde muy temprano. 

Para continuar con su negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo suelas, goma y moldes para los zapatos. En el futuro quiere tener otra zapatería para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Franklin, 50, lives along Guayaquil’s beltway (an urban perimeter in ecological decline). When he was a young man he wasn’t able to study and had to work in a shoe shop. Gradually he learned the skills and decided to use his savings to set up his own business. Although it was very difficult at the beginning, he continued with his small shoe shop, repairing shoes, sewing them and manufacturing them. Now, his entire family helps out in the shop; they work from very early in the day. To continue with his business he needs funds to buy soles, glue and shoe forms for the shoes. In the future, he’d like to have an additional shoe shop for his children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For soles, glue, shoe forms.

loans.name: Roza

texts.ru:
Roza jivet v Absheron regioane. Yey 41 let. Ona zamujem i imeyet 2 detey.Yeyo deti 17 i 20 let . Oni uchatsya ochen xorosho. Roze v etom biznese pomoqayet i muj  on pomoqayet yey privozit noviye tovari iz "Locbatan".

Roza uje 8 let v etom biznese .Teper ona nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi rasshirit prostranstvo i sdelat remont.
Ona qovorit chto yey ne xvatayet mesta dlya yeyo tovarov tak kak mnoqo novix modeley ona privozit.
texts.en:
Roza lives in the Absheron Region. She is married and has two children. Her children are 17 and 20 years old. They are very good students. Roza’s husband helps her out with the business too, delivering new goods from the Locbatan [Region]. Roza has been in this business for eight years already. She now needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to expand and renovate her store. She says that she does not have enough space for her goods as she gets many new models delivered.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to expand the store

loans.name: Jacques

texts.fr: Monsieur Jacques F. est un agent de sécurité âgé de 27 ans. Il mène en parallèle de l’élevage de porcs. Ainsi pour développer cette activité, elle souhaitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA  quelques bêtes. Monsieur Jacques F., célibataire, compte beaucoup sur cette activité pour diversifier et augmenter ses revenus afin de régler ses besoins et ceux de ses proches parents qui attendent beaucoup de lui
texts.en:
Mr. Jacques F., aged 27, is a security guard. Concurrently, he has a business raising pigs. To develop this business, he would therefore like a loan of 100,000 francs CFA for a few animals. Jacques is unmarried and is counting very much on this business to diversify and increase his revenues in order to cover his needs and those of his parents, who expect a lot of him.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pigs

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent M. is from the city of San Jose, Santiago City. He is 23 years old. Vincent is single. To make a living, Vincent owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling kitchen supplies, DVDs, and raincoats. Vincent has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vincent joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vincent has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell.
